billsco

...a man reaps what he sows.

 
 The bible states you reap what you sow but in the story of Christianity that is false. Christianity, as expressed in the salvation scheme, is based on reaping more or less than what you sow, and not on any fair, impartial measure. 
 
 Unless one believes a very narrow, specific thing, all the seeds one plants will lead to fallow ground. Conversely, all one needs to do is profess a certain belief and the bountiful rewards of reaping greatly exceed what was sown. The salvation plan is by no means fair in that regard.
 
 As an example, Bob lives a honest life, steadily working, paying his bills in a timely manner, contributing to society in a small but beneficial way. He loves his wife and children, and has been a good neighbor, but cannot for the life of him believe the Christian story. According to that story, Bob will definitely not reap the fruits of his sowing.
 
 Joe, meanwhile, is particularly ill-tempered and has been arrested for armed robbery and rape. He has been a continual burden on society, yet on his deathbed confesses that he fully believes the Christian story. According to the story, he is now going to reap much more than he ever sowed.
 
 Why would the bible proclaim this if the writer (I believe it was Paul) understood what the salvation plan entailed? Why do we allow Christians to utter this often-repeated saying and not call them on it?
Symbiote
Perhaps the phrase was meant, not as a metaphor, but in a strictly agricultural context. :)
Easyrider

The bible states you reap what you sow but in the story of Christianity that is false. Christianity, as expressed in the salvation scheme, is based on reaping more or less than what you sow, and not on any fair, impartial measure. As an example, Bob lives a honest life, steadily working, paying his bills in a timely manner, contributing to society in a small but beneficial way. He loves his wife and children, and has been a good neighbor, but cannot for the life of him believe the Christian story. According to that story, Bob will definitely not reap the fruits of his sowing.....Why do we allow Christians to utter this often-repeated saying and not call them on it?

 
 Well for one thing you didn't fairly represent the arguments above. The law of sowing and reaping, as you gave it, should have be given in context with the rest of Jesus' teachings, including his eternal plan of salvation. But generally speaking, if you work hard you'll reap a harvest. If you sow evil you'll reap evil (hell) in the end, even if that doesn't happen until the Judgment. As for Bob, he's a sinner like everyone else, and needs to repent and receive Jesus. As the Bible states, "..all have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God". 
 
 Recommend you read Romans chapters 1-4 (especially chapter 3), and also take note of the relationship between salvation and rewards in I Corinthians 3:11-15. Finally, a good study is recommended on the loss of eternal rewards in heaven, for those who are saved but have been careless about their works.
billsco

Well for one thing you didn't fairly represent the arguments above. The law of sowing and reaping, as you gave it, should have be given in context with the rest of Jesus' teachings, including his eternal plan of salvation. 
 
 
 That IS the crux of my argument, and one that specifically takes the salvation scheme-the central plan of Jesus--into account. My assertion is that regardless of the quality and quantity of seeds one plants, it has no relationship to what one reaps. You don't make clear what I am not fairly representing nor what is being taken out of context. 
 
 
 But generally speaking, if you work hard you'll reap a harvest. If you sow evil you'll reap evil (hell) in the end, even if that doesn't happen until the Judgment. 

 
 It is your contention from a careful reading of your above quote that good works will save you, bad works will doom you, yet the bible chapters in Romans which you linked to contradict this. Romans 3:28 makes it clear that we are "justified by faith without deeds". My example in the OP appears to be right on. Bob is going to fry, Joe will be trying on his harp. Neither fairly reaped what they sowed.
 
 
 As for Bob, he's a sinner like everyone else, and needs to repent and receive Jesus. As the Bible states, "..all have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God". 
 
 
 I agree that by many accounts God considers us worthless worms, but that is another confusing story. 
 
 
 Finally, a good study is recommended on the loss of eternal rewards in heaven, for those who are saved but have been careless about their works.

Billsco
 
 Here's something that might help also. I think it best to place in proper context the significance of works as it relates to salvation (justification) and rewards, which is most clearly expressed in I Corinthians 3:11-15:
 
 "For no one can lay any foundation other than the one already laid, which is Jesus Christ. If any man builds on this foundation using gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, or straw, his work will be shown for what it is, because the day will bring it to light. It will be revealed with fire, and the fire will test the quality of each man's work. If what he has built survives, he will receive his reward. If it is burned up, he will suffer loss; he himself will be saved, but only as one escaping through the flames." 
 
 
 The Full Life Study Bible provides these remarks on the above passage: 
 
 "HE WILL SUFFER LOSS: There is a future judgment for believers (I John 4:17) as to the degree of their faithfulness to God and the grace given to them during this life on earth (v.10; 4:2-5; 2 Cor.5:10). In that judgment there is the possibility that a believer, although receiving salvation, may experience great loss (Greek zemloo, meaning 'to suffer loss or damage'). The careless believer is in danger of suffering loss or damage in the following ways: (1) a feeling of shame at Christ's coming (2 Ti. 2:15; 1 John 2:28); (2) loss of his or her life's work for God (vv. 12-15); (3) loss of glory and honor before God (cf. Romans 2:7); (4) loss of opportunity for service and authority in heaven (Mt. 25:14-30); (5) a low position in heaven (Mt. 25:14-30); (6) loss of rewards (cf. v. 14-15); and (7) repayment for the wrong done to others (Col. 3:24-25).
 
 AS ONE ESCAPING THROUGH THE FLAMES:  'Escaping through the flames' is probably an expression meaning 'barely saved.' God will evaluate the quality of life, influence, teaching, and work in the church of each person. If his work is judged unworthy, he will lose his (heavenly) reward, yet he himself will be saved." ( Full Life 1755-56)
 
 Godly works do not result in justification, but are directed towards the edification and salvation of others, and eventually result in some type of heavenly rewards. For those who may have been saved just prior to death (the thief on the cross), there may not be any works to reward, yet their salvation is yet assured. It is my contention that once a person is regenerated, eventually, if they live long enough, there should be some sort of Godly works in their life (James chapter 2).

billsco

Easyrider,
 
 Please don't link to any more articles that drone on to infinity. I really prefer for you to argue your point in your own words, using bible passages if necessary to support any contentions. I read your linked articles this time but now I don't know who to respond to, you or the authors of the articles. If this is your M.O. I think it's only fair for me to link to pieces of my choosing which I will expect you to read, absorb, and respond to. 
 
 That said, I find the thinking behind the articles abhorrent. Somehow heaven is a very segregated place, where a careless believer (whatever that is) will occupy a low place in heaven; the hovels and slums across the tracks. The high rises on Snob Hill will be occupied by those who did the heavy lifting for God. Of course, heavy lifting means those who went the extra mile for God-for instance, the Christian crusaders who smashed in the skulls of the Muslim infidels. That's the kind of action which gets one a penthouse, a rare accomplishment these days. It's doubtful that simply typing responses and linking articles to a lowly infidel on the internet counts as heavy lifting. 
 
 And then there's this gem: 
 
 "This next verse tells us that God will reward some of us a hundredfold for having to leave family and friends in order to go to work for Him."
 
 Imagine, a special reward for abandoning your wife and kids. The author tells us-in a straight face-that this life is over in a blink of an eye. One's real priority therefore is to make sure all efforts are toward ensuring YOU store up YOUR heavenly rewards. Obviously the wifey and kids can store their own rewards, this is all about YOU.
 
 And what is the reward according to the author? A crown. Yes that's right, you get to wear a bejeweled crown on your head which distinguishes you in heaven from, say, the careless believer who stayed with and supported his family. He'll be crownless and get the key to some rundown, rat-infested hovel in the shadows of the sleek high-rises. 
 
 It's enough to make me want to set up a T-Shirt business at the pearly gates. "I did the heavy lifting for God and all I got was this lousy crown." 
 
 This place called heaven, as imagined by the articles you linked to, is beginning to sound terrible. It also reinforces in a powerful way my assertion that one doesn't reap what ones sows when it comes to the Christian scheme of things.
unkerpaulie

billsco, the law of sowing and reaping as the bible defines it is accurate and fair. living a "good life" (like bob) yeilds the results of living a good life: respect, social acceptance, fair credit, etc. the rewards of living a "bad life" (like joe) includes jail time, social rejection, mistrust, disrespect, etc. therefore, these men reap what they sow. nothing in christianity contradicts this
 
 the "fruit" of receiving heaven in the afterlife requires a different kind of "seed", namely salvation through jesus christ. this sowing and reaping is completely independent of living a "good life" or "bad life". its simply another "seed" altogether. you still reap what you sow
billsco

the "fruit" of receiving heaven in the afterlife requires a different kind of "seed", namely salvation through jesus christ. 

 
 That is where the rubber meets the road alright. That's where the imbalance of reaping to sowing manifests itself. In the salvation scheme, Joe becomes the big winner, despite what his earthly punishers did to him. Bob loses big time, for no other reason than possessing an honest opinion about the whole affair.
 
 If Christianity would accept good works as the touchstone to salvation, I might be more amenable. But it's based on faith alone and that is a terrible idea.
unkerpaulie

 If Christianity would accept good works as the touchstone to salvation, I might be more amenable. But it's based on faith alone and that is a terrible idea.

 its not a terrible idea at all. in fact, it makes perfect sense. the acceptance of salvation and the reward of heaven is linked in a 1-to-1 relationship. salvation is the only act by which heaven is reaped. heaven can only be attained through salvation
 
 i think the problem comes in when people have the expectation that "living good" should yeild the reawrd of heaven, and "living bad" should bring the reward of hell. while its correct to associate living good with being saved, living good is not the seed that yields heaven. the bible makes no such claim, and therefore you have no reason to have such an expectation
billsco

Perhaps I have no reason, perhaps I do. Think of it this way:
 
 Can you will yourself to believe anything you are told if it means getting a reward for it? I submit you can't and I can't imagine a creator forming a human mind which is wired for healthy skepticism and using it to eternally condemn the poor soul.
 
 I can accept some people can will themselves to believe anything. I can believe others will say they can but secretly have doubts. Others simply cannot. 
 
 Is this scheme fair to you, in a sowing and reaping sense? Should one be subjected to terrible consequences because of an honest answer to a fantastical question?
unkerpaulie

Perhaps I have no reason, perhaps I do. Think of it this way:
 
 Can you will yourself to believe anything you are told if it means getting a reward for it? I submit you can't and I can't imagine a creator forming a human mind which is wired for healthy skepticism and using it to eternally condemn the poor soul.
 
 I can accept some people can will themselves to believe anything. I can believe others will say they can but secretly have doubts. Others simply cannot. 

 whoa... are you saying that there are people incapable of willing themselves into believing anything? i seriously doubt that. the only thing that prevents someone from believing something is existing information in that person minds that contradicts the belief. this preexisting information is subject to adjustment through conscious effort. 
 
 for example, suppose you are deciding on whether to believe a bicycle can go 100 mph. the information existing in your mind about bikes and people's ability to pedal bikes would contradict this belief. therefore you would not believe the claim. however, you can willingly and consciously believe the new claim by breaking apart your previous contradictory beliefs about bikes. you could imagine a bike make of a much stronger material, with a higher gear-ratio or in conditions such as a steep slope, less air resistance, etc. eventually, you would be able to believe that a bicycle can travel at 100 mph
 
 in the case of small children, their brains contain no preexisting information about bikes, so there is nothing to contradict the belief that bicycles can go as fast as 100mph
 
Is this scheme fair to you, in a sowing and reaping sense? Should one be subjected to terrible consequences because of an honest answer to a fantastical question?

 the truth is "i can never believe that" is never an honest answer. more honest might be "i refuse to believe that" or "what i already know contradicts that claim"
 
 as to fairness, i still dont see what the problem is. beileving on jesus and accepting salvation is the seed that yeilds heaven. not believing on jesus and rejecting salvation is the seed that yeilds hell. think of it as, regardless how many apple seeds or vine seeds you plant, they have no bearing on the results that come from planting corn seeds.
 
 maybe it does seem unfair that "being good" is pretty much inconsequential to attaining heaven, but fear not, i have some great news that may alleviate your frustration...

 no matter how you think about it (that is, even if you believe that christianity is based in reality), doing good is like apple seeds, and accepting salvation is like corn seeds. can you say its not fair that you dont reap a single corn, even after planting apple seeds your whole life, and this one guy that planted 1 corn seed got a stalk of corn? no you would not, and there's nothing unfair, absurd or immoral about it.
 
 just as planting lots of apple seeds wont give you corn, doing lots of good deeds wont get you to heaven. its a simple sowing/reaping thing
